sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations with non-square matrices
message_1:
In a chemical reaction, 3 different compounds react to form 4 products. The reaction can be represented by the system of equations:

2x + y + z = 4
x + 4y + z = 8
x + 2y + 3z = 10

where x, y, and z are the amounts of the compounds and the numbers on the right-hand side represent the amount of each product formed.

Solve the system of equations to determine the amounts of each compound needed to produce the specified amount of products.
message_2:
To solve the system of equations, we can use the method of substitution or elimination. Here, we will use the elimination method.

First, we will eliminate x from the second and third equations. To do this, we will subtract the first equation from the second and third equations.

Subtracting the first equation from the second equation:
(x + 4y + z) - (2x + y + z) = 8 - 4
-1x + 3y = 4
=> x = 3y - 4 (1)

Subtracting the first equation from the third equation:
(x + 2y + 3z) - (2x + y + z) = 10 - 4
-x + y + 2z = 6
=> x = y + 2z - 6 (2)

Now, we will set equations (1) and (2) equal to each other and solve for y:
3y - 4 = y + 2z - 6
=> 2y = 2z - 2
=> y = z - 1 (3)

Now, we will substitute equation (3) back into equation (2) to solve for x:
x = (z - 1) + 2z - 6
=> x = 3z - 7 (4)

Now, we will substitute equations (3) and (4) back into the first equation to solve for z:
2(3z - 7) + (z - 1) + z = 4
=> 6z - 14 + z - 1 + z = 4
=> 8z = 19
=> z = 19/8

Now, we will substitute the value of z back into equations (3) and (4) to find the values of y and x:
y = (19/8) - 1
=> y = 11/8

x = 3(19/8) - 7
=> x = 57/8 - 56/8
=> x = 1/8

So, the amounts of the compounds needed to produce the specified amount of products are:
x = 1/8
y = 11/8
z = 19/8
